Paragraph.Text: the time needed for the witness’s testimony;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the party’s relationship to the witness;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an expert witness, a description of the expert witness’s qualifications; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: whether the party wants the witness to testify by means of live telecommunication.

Subsection.Text: The witness information provided to the Division must be accompanied by proof that it was provided to any other party.
Documents provided under this rule must be received by their recipients no later than 20 days before the date fixed for the hearing.
If a party does not provide the witness information, the witness must not testify at the hearing unless the Division allows them to testify.
In deciding whether to allow a witness to testify, the Division must consider any relevant factors, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the relevance and probative value of the proposed testimony; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the reason why the witness information was not provided.

Subsection.Text: A party who wants the Division to order a person to testify at a hearing must make a request to the Division for a summons, either orally at a proceeding or in writing.
In deciding whether to issue a summons, the Division must consider any relevant factors, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the necessity of the testimony to a full and proper hearing;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person’s ability to give that testimony; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: whether the person has agreed to be summoned as a witness.

Subsection.Text: If a party wants to use a summons, they must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: provide the summons to the person by hand;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide a copy of the summons to the Division, together with proof that it was provided to the person by hand; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: pay or offer to pay the person the applicable witness fees and travel expenses set out in Tariff A of the Federal Courts Rules.

Subsection.Text: If a person who is summoned to appear as a witness wants the summons cancelled, the person must make an application in writing to the Division.
The person must make the application in accordance with rule 37, but is not required to give evidence in an affidavit or statutory declaration.

If a person does not obey a summons to appear as a witness, the party who requested the summons may make a request to the Division orally at the hearing, or in writing, to issue a warrant for the person’s arrest.
A party who makes a written request for a warrant must provide supporting evidence by affidavit or statutory declaration.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Requirements for issue of arrest warrant
Subsection.Text: The Division must not issue a warrant unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person was provided the summons by hand or the person is avoiding being provided the summons;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person was paid or offered the applicable witness fees and travel expenses set out in Tariff A of the Federal Courts Rules;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the person did not appear at the hearing as required by the summons; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the person’s testimony is still needed for a full and proper hearing.

Subsection.Text: A warrant issued by the Division for the arrest of a person must include directions concerning detention or release.

Section.Text: If the Division excludes a witness from a hearing room, no person may communicate to the witness any evidence given while the witness was excluded unless allowed to do so by the Division or until the witness has finished testifying.

Heading.TitleText: Changing the Location of a Hearing

Subsection.Text: A party may make an application to the Division to change the location of a hearing.
The party must make the application in accordance with rule 37, but is not required to give evidence in an affidavit or statutory declaration.
Documents provided under this rule must be received by their recipients no later than 20 days before the date fixed for the hearing.
In deciding the application, the Division must consider any relevant factors, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: whether the party is residing in the location where the party wants the hearing to be held;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: whether a change of location would allow the hearing to be full and proper;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: whether a change of location would likely delay the hearing;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: how a change of location would affect the Division’s operation;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: how a change of location would affect the parties;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: whether a change of location is necessary in order to accommodate a vulnerable person; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: whether a hearing may be conducted by means of live telecommunication with the person who is the subject of the appeal.

Subsection.Text: Unless a party receives a decision from the Division allowing the application, the party must appear for the hearing at the location fixed and be ready to start or continue the hearing.

Heading.TitleText: Changing the Date or Time of a Hearing

Section.MarginalNote: Application to change date or time

Subsection.Text: A party may make an application to the Division to change the date or time fixed for a hearing.
The party must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: make the application in accordance with rule 37, but is not required to give evidence in an affidavit or statutory declaration; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: give at least six dates and times, within the period specified by the Division, on which the party is available to start or continue the hearing.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Notice of period specified by Division
Subsection.Text: The Division must provide notice of the period referred to in paragraph (2)(b) in a manner that will allow public access to it.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Hearing two working days or less away
Subsection.Text: If the party wants to make an application two working days or less before the date fixed for the hearing, the party must make the application orally on the date fixed for the hearing.
In deciding the application, the Division must consider any relevant factors, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a date and time that was fixed after the Division consulted or tried to consult the party, any exceptional circumstances for allowing the application;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when the party made the application;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the time the party has had to prepare for the hearing;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the efforts made by the party to be ready to start or continue the hearing;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a party who requests more time to obtain information in support of their arguments, the Division’s ability to proceed in the absence of that information without causing an injustice;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: whether the party has counsel;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the knowledge and experience of any counsel who represents the party;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: any previous delays and the reasons for them;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: whether the date and time fixed were peremptory;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: whether the change is required to accommodate a vulnerable person;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: whether allowing the application would unreasonably delay the hearing or likely cause an injustice; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: the nature and complexity of the matter to be heard.

Subsection.Text: If the party made a previous application that was denied, the Division must consider the reasons for the denial and must not allow the subsequent application unless there are exceptional circumstances supported by new evidence.

If a person who is the subject of an appeal makes the application for medical reasons, other than those related to their counsel, they must provide, together with the application, a legible, recently dated medical certificate signed by a qualified medical practitioner whose name and address are printed or stamped on the certificate. A person who has provided a copy of the certificate to the Division must provide the original document to the Division without delay.
The medical certificate must set out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the particulars of the medical condition, without specifying the diagnosis, that prevent the person from participating in the hearing on the date fixed for the hearing; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the date on which the person is expected to be able to participate in the hearing.

Subsection.Text: If a person who is the subject of an appeal fails to provide a medical certificate in accordance with subrules (7) and (8), the person must include in their application

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: particulars of any efforts they made to obtain the required medical certificate, supported by corroborating evidence;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: particulars of the medical reasons for the application, supported by corroborating evidence; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an explanation of how the medical condition prevents them from participating in the hearing on the date fixed for the hearing.

Subsection.Text: Unless a party receives a decision from the Division allowing the application, the party must appear for the hearing at the date and time fixed and be ready to start or continue the hearing.

In determining whether an appeal has been abandoned under subsection 168(1) of the Act after a date for a hearing has been fixed, the Division must give the appellant an opportunity to explain why the appeal should not be declared abandoned,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: immediately, if the appellant is present at the hearing and the Division considers that it is fair to do so; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any other case, by way of a special hearing, after notifying the appellant in writing.

Subsection.Text: The Division must consider, in deciding if the appeal should be declared abandoned, the explanation given by the appellant and any other relevant factors, including the fact that the appellant is ready to start or continue the proceedings.

If the appellant is the person who is the subject of the appeal and the explanation includes medical reasons, other than those related to their counsel, they must provide, together with the explanation, the original of a legible, recently dated medical certificate signed by a qualified medical practitioner whose name and address are printed or stamped on the certificate.
The medical certificate must set out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the particulars of the medical condition, without specifying the diagnosis, that prevented the person from pursuing their appeal; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the date on which the person is expected to be able to pursue their appeal.

Subsection.Text: If a person who is the subject of an appeal fails to provide a medical certificate in accordance with subrules (3) and (4), the person must include in their explanation

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: particulars of any efforts they made to obtain the required medical certificate, supported by corroborating evidence;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: particulars of the medical reasons included in the explanation, supported by corroborating evidence; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an explanation of how the medical condition prevented them from pursuing their appeal.

Subsection.Text: If the Division decides not to declare the appeal abandoned, it must start or continue the proceedings without delay.

Section.Text: These Rules come into force on the day on which section 110 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act comes into force, but if they are registered after that day, they come into force on the day on which they are registered.
